key_questions:
What is the MASC 2–SR?
The MASC 2–SR is a set of rating scales that is used to gather information about how the child is feeling

Why do children complete the MASC 2–SR?
Information from the child about his or her own thoughts, feelings, and behaviors is extremely important,
since the child is more aware of his/her feelings than anyone else

How does the MASC 2–SR work?
Benjamin Burdette (C

structured_content.summary:
Multidimensional Anxiety Scale for Children
2nd Edition–Self-Report
ver … 0067) engages in a
typical number of harm avoidance behaviors compared to other people his age
action_items:
This report is an interpretive aid and should not be provided to the parents, teachers, or youth, or used as
the sole basis for clinical diagnosis or intervention

To obtain a comprehensive view of the individual, information from this report
should be combined with information gathered from other psychometric measures, interviews, observations,
and available records

Administrators should review responses to specific items to ensure that these
interpretations apply

Interpreting MASC 2 Scores
Responses on the MASC 2 are combined to create 11 T-scores: MASC 2 Total Score, Separation
Anxiety/Phobias, Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD) Index, Social Anxiety (Total, Humiliation/Rejection,
Performance Fears), Obsessions & Compulsions, Physical Symptoms (Total, Tense/Restless, Panic), and
Harm Avoidance

Since the MASC 2 does not make formal diagnoses but instead indicates the
probability of one or more diagnoses, other clinically relevant information should also be carefully considered
in the assessment process

0067) tends to experience:
· Excessive checking
· Repetitive or ritualistic actions
· Scrupulosity (i

If these panic symptoms are unprovoked, then a formal diagnosis of panic
disorder should be considered

Intervention Suggestions
The MASC 2 provides an easy way to identify anxiety and Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD)
symptoms and to develop a treatment plan that includes syndromal and item-level targets

For
example, a youth who is already avoidant of settings in which he/she might have to speak up
becomes increasingly fearful and avoidant in the classroom

For
example, a youth with both separation and social disorders may need to address public speaking anxiety
symptoms before going away to camp, so he/she can ask for help, if necessary
unresolved_tensions:
Since the MASC 2 does not make formal diagnoses vs instead indicates the
probability of one or more diagnoses, other clinically relevant information should also be carefully considered
in the assessment process

As noted, these symptoms and signs do not take place in a vacuum vs rather are conditioned by the
youth’s environment
